text: "They're the best... beet and acorn cookies that I have ever eaten."
Hey what's up guys, welcome back to Binging with Babish. For this week, we're trying
Carol's Beet & Acorn Cookies... which of course, utilizes acorns that she foraged.
Ashwin: Well, the thing about foraging for acorns, Zander, is that you want to make sure-- [Babish] dude, dude... this is my show.
What're you-- what are you doing here?
Ashwin: Well, you weren't saying anything, you were just standing here so--
Babish: Well yeah, I do a voice-over in post production-- I'm not saying anything right now, I'm just moving my hands

around for emphasis.
Ashwin: Where the hell is that voice coming from?
Here, you know what? Jus-- just stand over there. That's Ashwin from Ashwin Enjoys Nature. He helped me
forage for these acorns that we're going to turn into *snaps* acorn flour.
Nah, I'm just kidding. I had to special order this crap from California.
So, I'm just sort of improvising this recipe using very basic cookie algorithms.
Combine acorn and white flour, a leavener (in this case, arrowroot powder,) a bit of cinammon for flavor,
and a bit of salt for flavor. Whisk to combine and it's time to talk about post-apocalyptic sweeteners. Now, it
looked like Carol was reaching for some cacao nibs, so we're gonna process 3 tbsp. in a mortar and pestle--
I don't know what you're giggling at; there's nothing funny about what I'm doing right now--
and then on top of that, apparently Carol uses beets for sweetness. Now, I think she would have better luck with
some fresh beets like these, but in the show, she opts for canned beets. Be very careful with these: they will stain

every--
Ashwin: And actually, what gives beets a red color is a

pigment called Betacyanin. Now, Betacyanin is--
Babish: Wha-- what... what the hell is that?
Ashwin: Oh, it's like a little thing I do in my episodes.
Babish: Get that out of here-- what font is that?

Ashwin: What? No... I was gonna use that, but okay.
Babish: He's just not getting how this works.
Anyway, we're going to puree our can of beets in a high powered blender-- do the same with a can of water
chestnuts-- and we're gonna mix those together with a quarter cup of vegetable shortening: a fat that
apparently has an indefinite shelf life. But don't trust me on that-- I just googled it.
Once those are well combined, we're going to add our dry ingredients and mix until a thick cookie dough forms.
... If you can even call this stuff cookie dough. Dole out some dollops onto a parchment lined baking sheet and
bake in a 350Â° F oven for about 15 minutes until you get these things, which don't look anything like the show.
There's just no way cookies are gonna look like that if you're putting beets and cacao nibs in there. And just as
I suspected, they look terrible, they taste terrible, and I hate them...
Hey Ashwin, you gotta come over here and try these. They're-- they're really good.
Ashwin: Mm.
Alright, let's see if we can try to make these tasty. I'm gonna start with coconut oil, some more beet puree,
a quarter cup of brown sugar, a little bit of vanilla paste. Whisk together to combine and-- op, I cannot forget--
the absolutely inexplicable addition of water chestnuts.
Same procedure as before, but backwards. We're combining the wet ingredients to add to the dry.
This time, I'm gonna use 3/4 cup each of the acorn flour and all purpose flour and a tbsp. or two of arrowroot,
our processed cacao nibs. Mix briefly on medium speed to combine before pouring in our beet mixture.
And because why not, have us some chocolate chips. After tasting, I realized it needed more sugar, so a little
bit of sugar, an egg for improved cookie structure, beat to combine, and form into balls. We're gonna try making
these into earthquake cookies, so roll in confectioner sugar, place on a lightly greased cookie sheet, and
bake at 350 for about 15 minutes until you are greeted with cookies made from beets, water chestnuts,
and acorn flour that are actually halfway edible. Now, if this was my first cookie after six years of a zombie
apocalypse, it'd be pretty good, but you guys would be better off just making literally any other cookie.
Hey guys, head on over to Ashwin Enjoys Nature to see how he found these ingredients, and if you like...
to see my face. He's a very funny guy, and he came to New York and helped me out to-- Holy! Jesus!

Dude, where did you even come from?
Ashwin: Oh, I was just hangin' out down here.
We don't show our faces on the show-- it's not how we do things.
Man, I don't know all your rules, ok? I've never seen this show before.
